CheckTitle: Amazon Cognito user pool requires Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
CheckType: Software and Configuration Checks/AWS Security Best Practices
Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/AWS Foundational Security Best Practices
Description: **Amazon Cognito user pools** with **MFA** set to `ON`, indicating an additional factor is enforced during authentication
Risk: Without **MFA**, password-only sign-in increases **account takeover** via phishing, brute force, and credential stuffing. Compromised accounts yield valid tokens to access data and APIs, alter configurations, and move laterally, eroding **confidentiality** and **integrity**, and potentially affecting **availability** through abuse.

Code.NativeIaC:
```yaml
# CloudFormation: Require MFA and enable TOTP
Resources:
  <example_resource_name>:
    Type: AWS::Cognito::UserPool
    Properties:
      MfaConfiguration: ON  # Critical: sets MFA to required
      SoftwareTokenMfaConfiguration:
        Enabled: true       # Critical: enables TOTP so ON is valid
```
Code.Other:
1. In AWS Console, go to Amazon Cognito > User pools
2. Select your user pool
3. Open Sign-in > Multi-factor authentication > Edit
4. Set MFA enforcement to Require MFA
5. Enable Authenticator app (TOTP) under MFA methods
6. Click Save changes

Recommendation.Text: Enable **MFA** at the user pool level (`Required` or risk-based) as a **defense-in-depth** control. Prefer **TOTP** or phishing-resistant methods over SMS. Require factor enrollment during onboarding, and enforce **least privilege** on downstream permissions. Complement with anomaly detection and session hardening to prevent and contain ATO.
